title: What dB level should I mix dialogue, music, and effects to for a film? - Quora

response.answer_text: Peak levels (which I assume is what you mean by “dB level”) don’t really matter. The main thing you need to worry about is RMS (“Root Mean Square”) loudness levels. Loudness is a more accurate way of measuring volume that relates to the way our ears hear sound. A sound with a high transient peak level won’t sound as loud to us as a sound that maintains at that peak level over a long period of time. That’s what RMS levels measure. Generally you want the master level of the mix to be between -8 and -14dB RMS. You’ll want to build the mix around that, but generally you want at least 6dB RMS of separation between the vocals and other parts of the mix to ensure clarity.

The levels on the output are set in post production but the level at which they are recorded must be clear. dB of around 75 is room - normal noises, a live band usually is about 100–110. Point of pain is about 125–150dB such as blaring megaphone political rallies or an expansion chamber on a racing grand prix motor cycle. I suggest you set your levels on your recording devices about mid to 75% and watch the peak indicators so that any loud sounds don’t peak. The editors and post sound mixers will do the rest.
